subject: Testing abstract classes
msgSnippet: Normally I like to test my abstract classes separately from any concrete implementations I might have. I might have something like this: public abstract
messageBody:
Normally I like to test my abstract classes separately from any
concrete implementations I might have. I might have something like this:

public abstract AbstractThingy {
// some concrete methods in here that need testing
...
}

Based on this, I would name my test class: AbstractThingyTest
(although it's not abstract itself).

When I run JUnit in Eclipse, everything is fine and dandy. Running it
from within Maven however seems to make this test not run. So I tried
renaming the test to simply: ThingyTest. When I run this, it does in
fact run.

Anyone else encountered something similar? I suspect it's a bug and it
should be looking for the keyword "abstract" instead of any file or
class with the word "Abstract" in it.

Thoughts?

Josh
